control.label: Good morning, Germany! This live blog is intended to keep users up to date with [CR]DevCon conversations. I’ll likely update roughly once at the change of each hour, [CR]so there’s no real reason to constantly hit refresh. If you don’t see an update on[CR]the hour, I’ll hold back up updating until the next hour. …

We apologize for the late notice, but for those of you in the Munich area we [CR]finally have a date and time for our Devs and Users Meet-up. We’ll be meeting at [CR]the NH München Dornach, Einsteinring 20. D-85609 Dornach. Munich at 19.30 (that’s[CR]7:30PM for Americans) on this Friday. Just head over to the hotel …

It’s been a busy year since XBMC’s 2012 Developers’ Conference. In that time, XBMC[CR]12.2 was released. The Raspberry Pi became one of the most used (if not the [CR]single most used) pieces of hardware to run XBMC. Hardware decoding in Android has[CR]become a real thing if only in alpha builds. PVR was added …

XBMC is a free and open source media[CR]player application developed by the[CR]XBMC Foundation, a non-profit [CR]technology consortium. XBMC is [CR]available for multiple operating-[CR]systems and hardware platforms, [CR]featuring a 10-foot user interface [CR]for use with televisions and remote [CR]controls. It allows users to play [CR]and view most videos, music, [CR]podcasts, and other digital media [CR]files from local and network storage[CR]media and the internet.
